p:
The highest MIC (2000 µg/mL) was detected for Aspergillus brasiliensis and Aspergillus niger, which showed a high resistance to both oils. Inhibition of the growth of Gram-negative bacteria such as Staphylococcus epidermidis and Escherichia coli was low for leaf oil (MIC = 1000 µg/mL), but always higher than that obtained by Sonboli et al.
28 and Asadollahi et al.
39 , who found an MIC of 1500 µg/mL against Escherichia coli. Surprisingly, the MIC (31.2 µg/mL) of flower oil against Escherichia coli, which is the main diarrhea-causing agent in humans, was significantly higher in comparison with the corresponding oil from leaves. It was similar to that provided by gentamicin (31.25 µg/mL), but significantly lower than that for rifampin (15.63 µg/mL).
